item.title: Saxon add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "Do not be angry with the rain; it simply does not know how to fall upwards." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Saxon add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "the liftman in the tube is an eternal necessity..." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Saxon add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "Pnin slowly walked under solemn pines. The sky was dying. He did not believe in an autocratic God. He did believe, dimly, in a democracy of ghosts. The souls of the dead, perhaps, formed committees, and these, in continuous session, attended the destinies of the quick." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Saxon add a quote by Nathaniel West
item.description: "But whether he was happy or not was hard to say. Probably he was neither, just as a plant is neither." -- Nathaniel West

item.title: Saxon add a quote by John Leonard
item.description: "Isn't post-modernism really one big cover-up for the failure of the French to write a truly interesting novel ever since a sports car ate [author:Albert Camus|957894]?" -- John Leonard

item.title: Saxon add a quote by Lorrie Moore
item.description: "How can it be described? How can any of it be described? The trip and the story of the trip are two different things. The narrator is the one who has stayed home, but then, afterward, presses her mouth upon the traveler’s mouth, in order to make the mouth work, to make the mouth say, say, say. One cannot go to a place and speak of it; one cannot both see and say, not really. One can go, and upon returning make a lot of hand motions and indications with the arms. The mouth itself, working at the speed of light, at the eye’s instructions, is necessarily struck still; so fast, so much to report, it hangs open and dumb as a gutted bell. All that unsayable life! That’s where the narrator comes in. The narrator comes with her kisses and mimicry and tidying up. The narrator comes and makes a slow, fake song of the mouth’s eager devastation." -- Lorrie Moore

item.title: Saxon add a quote by Flann O'Brien
item.description: "Is it life?" he answered, "I would rather be without it," he said, "for there is queer small utility in it. You cannot eat it or drink it or smoke it in your pipe, it does not keep the rain out and it is a poor armful in the dark if you strip it and take it to bed with you after a night of porter when you are shivering with the red passion. It is a great mistake and a thing better done without, like bed-jars and foreign bacon." -- Flann O'Brien

item.title: Saxon add a quote by Vladimir Nabokov
item.description: "I confess I do not believe in time. I like to fold my magic carpet, after use, in such a way as to superimpose one part of the pattern upon another. Let visitors trip. And the highest enjoyment of timelessness―in a landscape selected at random―is when I stand among rare butterflies and their food plants. This is ecstasy, and behind the ecstasy is something else, which is hard to explain. It is like a momentary vacuum into which rushes all that I love. A sense of oneness with sun and stone. A thrill of gratitude to whom it may concern―to the contrapuntal genius of human fate or to tender ghosts humoring a lucky mortal." -- Vladimir Nabokov

item.title: Saxon add a quote by Patti Smith
item.description: "I don't fuck much with the past but I fuck plenty with the future." -- Patti Smith
